Vishwesh Thakur wrote:

> Hello Shadab,
>  Heritrix makes use of an external api dnsjava for resolving dns 
> queries. dns java perhaps has its ownn caching system, 

It does (Uses soft references).

> takes care of timeouts and has its own cache cleaner as well, and all 
> you've to do to use it is just make api calls and the cleaner and 
> other stuff runs on it own.
>
> Regards
> Thakur
>
....

> I want to know, how the FetchDNS works??

Adding to Thakur's note, FetchDNS is responsible for getting any URL of 
a 'dns' scheme: e.g. dns:tcl.apache.org.  Everytime Heritrix trips over 
a new host, we first get a dns record for the newly discovered. We treat 
these dns URLs as we do any other adding them to the Frontier.  When 
comes time to fetch dns, the FetchHTTP skips the URL because it only 
does 'http?' whereas the FetchDNS fetcher, triggered by the 'dns' scheme 
on URL, 'fetches' dns by asking dnsjava to fetch the 'dns' URL.  dnsjava 
-- see dnsjava.org -- returns a dns A record from which Heritrix 
extracts IP of newly-discovered host which is used doing subsequent 
fetches of documents from the newly found host. We also write the dns to 
the ARC file. Below is an example of whats written:

dns:tcl.apache.org 192.168.1.254 20051103003416 text/dns 58
20051103003416
tcl.apache.org.         1800    IN      A       209.237.227.195

Yours,
St.Ack
